awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Scalable Mesh Routing to Augment Low-Power Wide Area Internet of Things (IoT) Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to enhance the understanding of wireless mesh networks and deep reinforcement learning algorithms in order to significantly expand the coverage and robustness, accelerating Internet of Things (IoT) adoption across the globe. These improvements to sensor systems seek to benefit a range of applications including public safety, smart agriculture, supply chain logistics, smart cities, wildlife monitoring, healthcare and other markets. The coverage and cost benefits are especially impactful for the U.S population in rural or economically-disadvantaged areas that lack cost effective connectivity and are unable to take advantage of the IoT benefits. Further, the project will enhance industry-academia partnership, enable the technology transition of innovations, and expand the participation of women in science, technology, enducation and mathematics (STEM).


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to enable scalable, longer-lasting, and higher-throughput Low Power Wide Area (LPWA) Internet of Things (IoT) networks by using LPWA IoT Mesh Augmentation (LIMA) devices to augment the connectivity between end-nodes and gateways in a cost-effective and easy-to-deploy manner. The mesh network of LIMA devices will adaptively multi-hop relay messages to maximize effective capacity and range. The teams seeks to augment the connectivity of LoRaWAN (a standard for Long Range Wide Area Networks) with a goal of increasing coverage range several-fold, reducing the battery drain of end-nodes, and enabling higher uplink bitrates. The core challenge for such LIMA is the development of a scalable multi-hop mesh routing protocol that, unlike existing protocols, accommodates the ultra-low bit rates that characterize LPWANs, and is generalizable across the diverse applications of LPWAN technology. The LIMA solution builds upon two synergistic innovations: (a) embedded-control routing, that uses a very small amount of bits in the data packet header in lieu of control packets, and thereby achieves scalability and energy-efficiency in ultra-low-capacity, energy-constrained networks and (b) relational deep reinforcement learning based routing that combines Reinforcement Learning and Deep Neural Networks (DeepRL) with the use of relational features to learn routing policies that adapt to a variety of link dynamics and traffic conditions. The LIMA solution does not require changes to end-nodes. The anticipated technical deliverables include mesh networking software, a simulation model, a 4-node prototype using a LoRa integrated circuit, and experimental analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The last decade has seen an explosion in the use of Low Power Wide Area Networks (LPWANs) for applications such as smart metering, public safety, precision agriculture, environment and infrastructure monitoring, supply chain management and several others. In an LPWAN, sensors communicate short burst data over several miles to a server on the Internet, where data analytics provide actionable insights. Current LPWAN standards, however, have several structural shortcomings that prevent the technology from being adopted in a truly universal fashion and fulfilling its potential. These barriers include: a "star" network topology which limits range and has single-failure points, the difficulty and cost of deployment in remote areas, and high energy consumption for long range communications. 

We have developed a novel approach to combating the limitations of current LPWANs using mesh networking technology. In particular, we have developed an LPWA IoT Mesh Augmentation (LIMA) device that can be placed in any existing or new LoRaWAN (a prominent LPWAN standard) to provide scalable multi-hop mesh networked connectivity between end-nodes and gateways.  The LIMA device can be used to increase coverage range well beyond the LoRa single-hop range, reduce energy consumption of devices, reduce infrastructure cost and increase robustness. LIMA provides these benefits without requiring any changes to the end-devices (sensors), the servers or to the LoRaWAN standard and therefore can easily be deployed within existing LoRaWAN systems.

LIMA augments an existing LoRaWAN system using LIMA Routers (LR) that run a novel mesh networking protocol based loosely on goTenna?s Aspen Grove protocol for peer-to-peer off-grid mesh networking that automatically pick up LoRa packets from the sensors and multi-hop relay them to a LIMA Gateway (LG). This is especially useful in remote areas where there is no wireline power and/or backhaul connectivity, due to which LoRaWAN Gateways cannot be deployed. LIMA Routers do not require backhaul and can be run on solar power. The LIMA protocol also works with the LoRaWAN Adaptive Data Rate (ADR) mechanism to reduce the transmit power of the sensor so that it only needs to reach the nearest LIMA Router rather than the typically much further Gateway. This significantly increases the battery lifetime of the sensors, requiring far fewer trips to replace batteries in remote areas. Finally, LIMA supports both uplink and downlink transmissions as well as over-the-air join requests.

Wesleyan University (subawardee on the project) has developed novel techniques for routing in mesh networks using Deep Reinforcement Learning (DeepRL) and showed that it offers significant performance benefits over traditional techniques. We have integrated Wesleyan's DeepRL-based routing with goTenna?s LIMA to develop a new mechanism called DeepRL LIMA (or DR-LIMA). This is one of the few studies on the application of DeepRL in IoT in general and LoRaWAN in particular.

We have simulated the performance of both LIMA and DR-LIMA in a range of scenarios and compared it with the performance of pure LoRaWAN. Our simulations showed that, compared to LoRaWAN, the LIMA Packet Delivery Ratio can be up to 4x higher, its energy consumption for devices up to 6x lower, and latency up to 2x lower. We also showed that DR-LIMA can slightly outperform LIMA in certain conditions, and identified opportunities for further improvement. We have also built a prototype LIMA router and LIMA gateway by modifying the software on an off-the-shelf commercial gateway product and tested it both using an indoor attenuation-based test setup as well as outdoors in Brooklyn around goTenna's headquarters. We showed that LIMA improves range without modifying the end-devices or server. We demonstrated multi-hop joining and authentication, and adaptive data rate to reduce energy consumption. Even with a single LIMA router, the range can be extended 2x, transmit power by 12 dB and packet duration by 6x, resulting in considerable energy savings.

LIMA can be used as part of a new or existing private LoRaWAN that needs to extend coverage area or reduce energy consumption, but additional gateways are difficult to place because of lack of power, internet backhaul or cost. LIMA mesh routers can be placed in strategic locations and the network can be expanded and device lifetime increased. It can also be useful in public infrastructure networks such as those provided by Senet, Loriot, Actility, incentivized networks such as Helium and specialized applications such as Amazon Sidewalk.  In many of these networks, there are significant coverage gaps. LIMA offers a way to fill those coverage gaps without adding expensive and sometimes impossible to deploy LoRaWAN gateways. 

To summarize, we have created a novel technology called LIMA that augments LoRaWAN with mesh networking to dramatically increase coverage and sensor lifetime without requiring changes to the LoRaWAN standard, end devices or the servers. We believe LIMA is the first technology to have these features and can be a valuable addition to LPWANs.
